content.description:
This problem provides good, if not immediately endearing climbing. The footholds are sparse, slick and never in the optimal location for the moves they support. Handholds are off-balance sidepulls and odd crack pod finger lock pockets. Most moves, from bottom to fluttery topout, feel insecure. From the first good topout holds, relax, breathe, and slowly climb around the blunt arete to the left. These moves are easier than the climb proper, but you're way off the ground, probably pumped and no longer over the pads. Downclimb the 5.7, broken corner to the left of the problem.

This problem would be a poor choice for a climber who sometimes sends 5.10s or has no head for highballs. A fall from higher moves, even onto pads, could have you in a cast or casts all summer. Be safe!
content.protection: At least one pad, preferably three. A spotter or three might be nice, but who's got friends?
content.location:
From the parking at the downstream side of tunnel one, walk down the well-established approach trail till it meets the water's edge. On your right, at the first clean section of the cliff, is a section of face with discontinuous crack system holds vaguely describing a tall, somewhat scary problem.

The steep blunt arete to the left may go as a significantly harder problem. Starts from cool undercling.

content.description:
The crux comes right from the start.  The rock here is somewhat polished and the holds are small.  I think it is harder than 10c, but that is what it is rated in the newest guidebook.  You can get small cams in about 10 feet up (really small).  Above this, the climbing gets easier and you pass an old bolt without a hanger.  The top joins "

Creek Corner

," and the two routes share the same anchor.
content.protection: Standard rack.  Lots of thin cams are helpful.  It has a two bolt anchor.
content.location: In the center of the largest rock in the area, start in a thin seam.  There is some faded graffiti at the start.  There is a small, right-facing dihedral about 20 feet up.  There is an anchor up top from which to descend.

content.description: This route is not bad if you are in the area and gives you easy access to the bolt anchor if you wish to top-rope something harder.  The crux is in the big left-facing dihedral near the top.  There is lots of protection on the climb.  It is a fairly interesting route close to the road and Golden itself.
content.location:
This is on the first rock you come to in the area.  It's not very big, but it looks like the most climbable rock in the area.

You start on easy rock to the left of a steep face with graffiti.  There is a tree close to the rock at the start.  There are broken cracks here, and you head to the right as you climb until you are in a big, left-facing dihedral.

There is a two bolt anchor to descend from at the top.
